trial_identification.studytitle: A novel sensory nerve stimulator to improve neuropathy in patients with diabetes
trial_identification.scientifictitle: The use of low frequency transcutaneous sensory nerve stimulation to improve sensory nerve function and symptoms in people with diabetic peripheral neuropathy

interventions.interventions: Double blind placebo randomised controlled trial of low frequency sensory electrical nerve stimulation within two different population groups over 12 weeks of treatment.

primaryOutcome.outcome: Comparison of the effect of treatment on vascular measures
primaryOutcome.timepoint: From baseline to 12 weeks post treatment

primaryOutcome.outcome: Comparison of the effect of treatment on neuronal measures
primaryOutcome.timepoint: From baseline to 12 weeks post treatment

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Comparison of the effect of treatment on subjective sensory measures.
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: From baseline to 12 weeks post treatment.

eligibility.inclusivecriteria: Group 1: Persons aged 55 to 65, with known diabetes duration of up to 5 years.Group 2: Persons aged 55 to 75, with known diabetes duration of up to 10 years.DPN diagnosed as insensate to 10g monofilament or reduced vibration below 4octals 128Hz graduated tuning fork.
eligibility.exclusivecriteria: Inability to consent to the research, an above or below-knee amputation, cigarette smoking.

trial_design.concealment: Allocation is concealed for the duration of the trial in sealed envelopes
trial_design.sequence: Block randomisation to ensure randomisation of placebo and active is even regardless of sample size, with the random allocation sequence formulated by using a random number table in excel

secondarysponsor.sponsorname: University of Melbourne, Department of Biochemistry and Molecular Biology

contact.name: Rajna Ogrin
contact.address: Department of Biochemistry and Molecular Biology University of Melbourne Parkville VIC 3010
